Overall production expansion is likely to be delayed and with a strong set of existing assets in the suite of high-quality projects, Rio Tinto will be well positioned to take advantage of this recovery.

Moving on to energy and minerals. Energy and Minerals Group had a very good year in 2008 with record earnings including a 600% increase in earnings in Rio Tinto coal Australia. Substantial higher thermal and coking-coal prices were a result of strong Asian demand, coinciding with constrained supply for the eastern seaboard of Australia. We also continue to focus on increasing volume of coking and semi-soft coal over thermal coal for most of the year to take advantage of higher relative prices. Of course that's changed over the past few months.

The uranium business saw the benefit of higher realized prices as old contracts continue to be replaced with newer contracts in this higher priced environment. Our uranium business was especially attractive due to the increasing uncertainty of our production increases previously scheduled by some of our competitors. The Group's Queensland coal operations recovered well from the weather-related disruptions in the first quarter and we were able to take up additional port allocation in both Queensland and New South Wales. We were less affected than others by the first quarter rainfall. And this allowed us to see the benefits of higher contract coal prices in the second quarter.

Cutbacks at steel production are expected to reduce demand for metallurgical coals using the production process. The demand level for thermal coals remains relatively resilient and price levels have recently stabilized, although the outlook for coking coal is certainly more uncertain.
The Clermont project remains on schedule to be production on stream for earlier 2010 to replace production from Pilbara Fall , as it nears the end of its scheduled time life.

The Group's iron and titanium operations performed well in 2008 from higher volumes and higher prices reflecting strong global demand for these products from developing nations. In December, we produced the first Ilmenite from a 750,000 ton per year Mineral Sands project in Madagascar.

This will be the landmark project for sustainable development and excellent example of the delivery of the successful major greenfield project in an emerging country. The Group's energy and mineral business is well positioned to benefit from strong markets in the future as a number two fuel and coal producer in Australia and the U.S., the number two uranium and borate producer worldwide and the number one global producer of titanium dioxide feedstocks.
Thank you and I believe it's now over to you Guy.

Thank you again, Tom. Now let me start with an analysis of how we achieved record earnings in 2008. We have set this out using the usual waterfall chart format. Higher prices benefited earnings by $5 billion, as we experienced strong pricing for traded metals through the first three quarters of the year and of course, large increases in the price of our bulk products in the first half.

We've included a breakdown of the price variants as an appendix to the presentation. We experienced dramatic swings in currencies relative to the dollar during the year, but the effect on average exchange rates was not very significant resulting in a benefit of $299 million. I'd like to remind you of the natural hedge between currency exchange rates and the movement in traded metal prices.

The earnings variants attributable to volume increases was $233 million, reflecting in particular strong growth in iron ore and coal volumes in addition to the impact of volumes from the inclusion of Alcan for the full year. This was partly offset by a grade-related decline in copper and molybdenum, with gold volumes also being affected. Again a break down of the volume variants is included as an appendix to the presentation.

Turning to costs, inflation and energy prices reduced earnings by 336 million and 219 million respectively. Cash cost increases reduced earnings by $882 million. The increase in costs includes the impact of low volumes on unit cost for copper as we highlighted in the fourth quarter operations review and rising input costs for supplies used in running our business. We are now starting to see a decline in input costs, albeit with a lag with further benefits expected to come through in 2009.

Finally there were some individual tax and other charges which reduced earnings collectively by $1.2 billion. The most significant item was a negative net interest cost variant of $765 million related to the Alcan acquisition debt, as well there was a higher effective tax rate from the absence of the 2007 Canadian tax rate benefit. So this brings us eventually to the excellent annual earnings figure of $10.3 billion.

Moving on to our cash flow, the Group's cash flow from operations increased 64% to a record $28.7 billion. This reflects the strong cash generative capabilities of our assets, even under challenging economic conditions during the last quarter of 2008. Cash flows were supported by record bulk prices and good markets for copper and aluminum for the first three quarters. These cash flows supported substantial net debt repayments and a significant capital expenditure program.

As Tom has already mentioned, the changed economic environment has required us to reflect on each of our projects and we are committed to reducing capital expenditures to approximately $4 billion in 2009. We'll also be maintaining dividends for 2008 at $1.36 per share consistent with our longstanding progressive dividend policy which has either held dividends flat or increased them through all points through the economic cycle. These actions along with a reduction in annual operating cost of $2.5 billion in 2010 and the continuation of an expanded divestment process will enable us to continue generating strong cash flows to meet our commitments.

The excellent cash flow from operations and divestments resulted in reducing net debt by 14% or $6.5 billion. Our commitment to reduce net debt by $10 billion by the end of 2009 remains fully in place. The sole covenant under the Alcan facilities is a ratio of net debt to underlying EBITDA of 4.5 times. In 2008, we comfortably met this covenant with a ratio of only 1.7 times. Although the use of our available facilities of $9.4 billion would not assist us with reducing our net debt by $10 billion, it nevertheless provides additional flexibility in meeting our commitments.

We are not complacent regarding our debt position. With the recent announced operating cost and the capital cost cuts, this year's divestments and of course the announcement today of the strategic partnership with Chinalco, we are over delivering on our commitment to reduce net debt by $10 billion during 2009.

Turning to impairment charges; net earnings of $3.7 billion include an impairment charge of $8.4 billion, of which $7.9 billion relates to the Group's aluminum business. The acquisition price of Alcan anticipated significant growth in smelter and refinery capacity. We're following the recent weakening in economic and market circumstances, many of these growth projects have been deferred.

These deferrals together with the weak economic environment and increases in input costs have resulted in this impairment charge. Even though growth options contribute limited value in assessing the level of impairment under accounting standards, let me reassure you that our view remains that Rio Tinto would extract significant value from these options in the longer term.

The weakening economic circumstances also resulted in impairments of other assets and the majority of those related to high smelt in Diavik. On divestments, during 2008, we achieved divestments of $3 billion with the sales of our interest in Cote's Greens Creek and La Quinta uranium asset.

In December 2008, we announced our intention to expand the scope of assets targeted for divestment. And in just two months, we've made good progress with divestments totaling 1.7 billion from the sale of Corumbá, our potash assets and Ningxia aluminum smelter in China. The prices achieved for these assets definitely represent full value and they demonstrate the depth and quality of our asset portfolio. They also illustrate our ability to unlock value for shareholders despite tough credit markets and economic conditions. We believe that the Chinalco transaction announced today continues this longstanding commitment to value.

The asset values we are realizing in today's conditions are outstanding and they would have been strong even before the downturn. We remain committed to our asset divestment program but the Chinalco transaction allows us to be selective as we continue with the divestment of our non-core assets. As we have said previously, in all our divestments, we're determined that we will only enter into a transaction at the right price. Value remains our primary consideration.
Now back to you Tom.

Thank you, Guy. So in conclusion, while the year has certainly ended on a different note from the beginning, overall the Group put in a strong performance. Underlying earnings were up 38% to a record 10.3 billion, underpinned by strong market conditions at least in the first nine months of 2008.

During the fourth quarter, the markets that we and everyone else operate in changed dramatically. We have adapted quickly to the rapid decline in our markets and our price, preserving value for shareholders by conserving cash flow and reducing levels of debt. We will not be complacent and we will continue to diligently review our operations and take those necessary and appropriate actions where necessary. At no time have large scale low-cost assets been more important. In addition to the suite of tier 1 assets, product diversity and broad geographic spread of operations, we'll continue to provide strong cash flows throughout the cycle. We will not limit our growth options, these options are being maintained by maintaining flexibility, enabling a quick response when there are positive signs of underlying demand for our products.

The world economy has slowed much more rapidly than anyone would have expected in the middle of last year. And a sustained recovery is not expected in the near term. However, we do believe the fundamentals in the Chinese and other fast-growing markets like India remain intact and industry's long-term prospects remain positive. Despite these current challenging circumstances and conditions the Group's strategy remains the same; to maximize shareholder value through excellence in mining and operating a large scale low-cost assets with an emphasis on quality. And this strategy will continue to be value generative for our shareholders.
With that thank you and I will take some questions. Nigel if you want to step up, it will be great.
So let's kick off here in the auditorium. First question please?

Thanks, Sam Catalano, from Macquarie again. Perhaps a question for Vivek just with regards to cost curves, clearly there we mentioned them coming down earlier. I guess which commodities would you see the sharpest decline in the cost curve and particularly the shape of that curve?

Thanks. Your question is which line prices will I think will come down fastest. I'm not going to -- look I don't think, what we probably find is that you will see reductions in average costs across a whole range of sectors. And we're seeing those all the time costs for example explosives, fuel costs and then they just bring down the average for everyone. We will probably also see very big changes in costs which, across the industries which are very challenged at the moment. So for example, with aluminum we would expect to see the low cost -- the high cost smelter shuts progressively over time. And therefore putting up the price so that we get something that's more consistent with a sustainable outcome. So there the relationship between costs and prices might differ a bit. But every sector is a bit different, every cost curve is a bit different.
Yeah, here you go.

Hi, it's Charles Kernot from Evolution. Actually I had some questions perhaps a little bit more for Chinalco, but perhaps you can help to answer them. First it relates just to the packaging business, clearly packaging or downstream aluminum fabrication is an area in which they are interested. However, it's an area the Chinese development is sort of lagging behind where we are or where Alcan is. Was there any interest expressed in the packaging business by Chinalco, and what sort of discussions did you have on that?

The second question relates to, and I have had some experience on this in the past to the difficulty in getting NDRC approval from the Chinese authorities, which I think is required to externalize finance. And associated with that why does the break fee in work one way? Wouldn't it be normal in this type of transaction for it to work both ways if Chinalco can't come up with the money on time. And I'll leave it at that Tom?

Maybe, I will start with the NDRC point. I thought Guy, then you comment on the packaging downstream and the break fee point. Now as we report, Paul and I within the past few weeks have met with senior officials of NDRC and certainly I think there has been a constructive engagement between Chinalco and the NDRC. In terms of recognizing the importance NDRC has in the approval of any investment, foreign investment within China, and certainly Chinalco has expressed to us and we've reaffirmed for ourselves the NDRC is strongly in support of this.
Guy?

About packaging, in point of fact, Chinalco did not express much interest in that assets sale. So unfortunately, they didn't participate in the presses, which we have been running. And on the question of the break fee, you understand that this is a package deal there also sort of elements in which we've had to give here and take that. And one of the things that we did agree to give up was an attempt to secure a break fee in the other direction. But as Tom has said, while one can never be fully confident of these things, we do -- we have had some very reassuring statements made by a very senior Chinese official. So let's hope that eventuality doesn't arrive.
I think it's fair to say that in all of our receptions with senior Chinese leadership, they've recognized that the world will be watching how this transaction proceeds towards various approvals.
Any further questions, here? Yeah.

Nick Moore of RBS . Exploration is almost the future of a company; that's how it grows. We've heard earlier about this exploration initiative and you made a very good point that many of these new mineral resources are in emerging countries. With regard to that, and obviously we went for that situation, where we had a fear of running out of resources is now surplus. But for the long term, this actually could be very exciting initiative. If you do make an exciting discovery within China, do you get sort of first putting on these or is there any requirements to allow Chinalco to run these? How is that going to work? Because this potentially could be a real mineral box for years?

Thank you Nick. The exploration in China has not escaped my attention. As you know, I've had a long -- experienced a lot of my career equipment first job had been in the area of exploration. We have been exploring or trying to explore in China since 1994. Frankly, it's been very difficult for us to get the access to the ground that we wanted to have.

And within China, it's not only getting the exploration permit, but also getting the continuation of those exploration permits with what would be assurances to move into mine improvements. And I think that we've had that 10 years of slow experience with we know what we would need to do to have competitive advantage. And I certainly from my perspective, and my exploration background -- again my -- probably exploration very closely ever since the mid-1990s. I do believe this provides us with a competitive edge for exploration. And I do believe that China is under explored and we could opportunities. The fact that the Oyu Tolgoi deposit, which you all know is probably the best undeveloped copper deposit in the world, sits 80 kilometer away from the Chinese border, is evidence of the fact that there is perspective terrain.
Okay. Any further questions.
Sam Fischer Cazenove. I was very confused about the decision to hold the dividend in lights of the capital that you are raising, why didn't you suspend that and so for your answers to Chinalco?

I'll make a brief comment and perhaps Guy can come on to that. I think we -- and it's deep in the Rio Tinto culture attaching almost importance to the long term dividend promise that the company has had of progressive dividend policy, which means not going backwards. I think had we moved towards one or two other options we might have looked at that, but in terms of the option, we've decided to go, we felt to hold the dividend was the right thing to do.
Guy, do you want to add to that?

I don't think there is much to add. I mean I think the integrity of that some have record is something that we felt was very important. It was something just short of a promise to our shareholders that we would maintain a progressive dividend. Of course we debated which assets should be in and which assets should be out of the package with Chinalco. And I think the eventual outcome was one which both sides felt comfortable with. So well I understand your question, I think it has to be in that context.
Okay. Guy, while you are -- perhaps you might have to take some questions in Melbourne.
Okay, Neil , do you want to take off?

Thank you. Steve Goodwill from Goldman Sachs. Just on our -- you have saved an average price issue. I think you said of the $1.18. And given the sensitivities you're giving us and given where stock prices are. And I mean your earnings this year, its spot price is going to be very well indeed.

Can you just give us some idea, what measures you can take in aluminum, what you will do? And also could you just give us some feel for how costs are going to come down in the aluminum business? Is there a significant like and sort of what percentage of the price fall that we see in aluminum will come through in costs?

Thank you Neil, maybe I will tackle and Guy, if you want to add anything to this. What we saw during the course of 2008 would have been a lagging increase in some of the cost inputs particularly elements around the coke pitch, caustic that drove up the overall cost structure. And again I would anticipate them coming down. But there is a time lag on them coming up, and I think we will see the time lag, we're still seeing it coming down in 2009.

We've recognized in this $0.60 aluminum price environment that all, but those first and second quartile operations even with rigorous costs containment will be very, very challenged and marginal. We have certainly gone through already two phrases of smelter shut down. We certainly have planning in place for further shut downs.

And that's all part of the overall sequencing of what any smelting company would be doing in this particular market, and we recognize that this involves that only the aluminum business. But also the impact on stakeholders and local community. So we're quite sensitive to those areas.

Jacynthe Côté has come in a very challenging time in the business and but I am absolutely confident she is focused entirely on the rigorous cost reduction. We've already within our first two weeks in the role she has already put in place very significant overhead and organizational cost reductions. And we are pushing for further cost reductions and efficiency improvements at each of the smelters.

We cannot rely on the fact that we've cost operations for that in itself puts a close through the storm. We've got to tackle our lowest cost operations as aggressively as our higher cost operations. And again at these prices, we will have some of our higher cost operations, which will be marginal and which will be tested some in the fairly near-term as the conditions dictate.

Perhaps I can just add a couple of comments. I mean difficult is the situation is for us. I think we are fairing better than the competition; thanks to the quality of the assets that we have in bauxite, aluminum, and smelting. I'll just add a couple of points. One is that in addition to the fact is that Tom mentioned, there are some other exogenous factors that favor us.

One is the fall in the oil price, and the others the fall in the currencies in most of the countries that we produce other bauxite or aluminum in. And those effects were not very much until late in 2008. So the costs on average during the year were affected by high input prices and stronger currencies.

The other thing that perhaps already mentioned is that the synergies, which were still delivering more than expected, again a kick in increasing as 2009 continues. So I'm not saying it's easy and isn't easy, but I think we are doing everything that we can. So next question here in Melbourne.

Couple of questions, firstly with the announcement late last year early this year regarding redundancies that sort of thing in preparing the asset bites for the current economic conditions. Are you able to give us some guidance on what the cost impact of making those decisions might be for this half of calendar '09. Secondly, you had made some substantial final spot sales through the course of 2008. Which spot prices holding up relatively well at the moment would you consider selling into spot market, if there is still some push back on your contracted customers. And then finally just in terms of some guidance around the net interest bill for our non-place.
Guy, would you want to talk about the cost impact of the redundancies and the last question? I'll talk about the spot iron ore business.
Okay.
Again, I think --
I'll have to -- do you want to -- go ahead, Tom.

Thank you. Yeah Craig, I mean we -- as you know, we said early in 2008 that we would be selling into the spot market and certainly it was a lot nicer time to be selling in the spot market $180 per ton than in the 60 $70 per ton range. I am very pleased that we got them out early in the cycle. I think it's fair to say as we said back in November of 2007 that we will always look at a mix of marketing activities, long-term contracts, hybrids spots et cetera. We will continue to explore that mix in this particular market, recognizing first and foremost. We want to look after those long-term contractive customers and that's what we have been doing.

There have been some lower levels of spot business in these markets, and certainly we recognize that we have seen some of an uplift. We've increased some of our shipments in the past few weeks, I think to some extent the Baltic Index has gone up, because we've probably put on more charted vessels than would have been the case in November and December.

Craig, I can't put my hands, I'm afraid, right now, on the cost of the redundancies. It was given, if I remember, in the release that we did on the 10th of December. I will give it to analysts when I brief them tomorrow. And make sure that you have had it. I'm not sure we will break it down there by --
I think it was just over $1 billion actually.
Now on the net interest number, you will see that we have -- you will see while the debt -- if I give about 400 million, it hasn't --
400 million; that's 400 million; I'm sorry.

--the receipt of the 850 million for the potash sale, which was -- which we reported a few days ago. On that, we are paying 3% approximately. That is to say we are paying between the 32 and 42 basis points over LIBOR on the outcome debt. That will change when it is repaid, and it will be substituted impart by no interest, because we'll be using the proceeds of the asset sales. And then it will be substituted by a 9.2% on average coupon under the new convertible bond. So I think that I can't give you a projected average, because I can't tell you the exact date at which this will close, but I think those are the building blocks for that calculation.
Guy, just to clarify, the revenue in number, the cost is 400 million. I was a bit worried, I thought 100 billion was a bit --
Yeah, quite right; billion was the saving, wasn't it? And I think we should move to Sydney actually. Stephen, you still there?
One more question here, Warne, if that's all right, Nigel. Sorry, I cut Warne off; I'm feeling a bit guilty over that.

Thanks Guy. A question -- actually two questions. One on QMM; this bringing some recent protocol such one risk there. And so whether it's impacted to start up in the operations. And also the trend development that you had a couple of weeks ago, what impact does that market have on shipping the first half? Thank you.

Thank you, Warne. I will cover both of these questions. At QMM, there have been some social unrest within Madagascar; most of it's been in the capital city, Tana; it has stabilized since. A few weeks ago, it has been unfortunate and we've had seen limited effects within the four to five locations, which is as you know is on the other side the country from Tana. I'd say overall it had no real effect on our start-up timing although and some days we had local residents standing in front of the road going to the site and we've managed that very closely with local Porticon authorities.

On the train derailment, it occurred on the double track part of the line. I think it took us about four days to recover one of the tracks in line of and few days after that to recover the second. I would not say that it will have a material effect on first half shipments. Of course as you know, probably what causes the most material effect in the first half would be the cyclone season and unfortunately, we're still in the middle of that. We've been not onward -- not too affected by it so far.

Okay, I have some questions here Nigel. Tim Gerard from Earlstock, in Sydney. Two questions, the first on iron ore and second on aluminum. With regard to the possible expansion, the 100 million ton expansion, you are obviously very, very circumspect about that and we can understand on a global basis. But given China's reliance on to some extent on the high-cost domestic ore, BHP pushing ahead aggressively with its expansions and Australia's market share in China only about 40% despite the freight advantage. Could you just comment please on why you are not pushing ahead more aggressively with that, especially considering that you're probably going to be getting $5 billion in from Chinalco soon rather than later? So that's the first question.

And the second question just with regard to the aluminum smelters, for some reason both Anglesea and Anzus had a disastrous year because of problems with transformers and I guess it doesn't sound like a big deal, but what kind of risk is there to your other smelters in the Group from underpinning your transformer maintenance programs?

Thank you, Tim maybe I can tackle both of those. First of all on iron ore, if any one had clairvoyance as to how we will come out of this global recovery, whether it gets worse, how it gets better, when it gets better I think we all have more certainty and more confidence in expanding through downturn. The sheer unprecedented nature of what we have been seeing and the contributing causes of this downturn I think poses considerable challenge for industry that global uptake in the global steel markets.

And at this point in time I don't see what I would call the credible and a meaningful signs of an economic recovery that would cause us to again to make those significant capital investments. So I think that is prudent and realistic in this current capital horizon. Certainly, Tim in my discussion with other two executives and other industries and seeing the global nature of what we are all experiencing, that deal will probably more commonly held than an anomaly. The fact that we have the ability to expand at our election, at our convenience, the fact that the Chinalco transaction gives us the financial flexibility to expand at our election, at our convenience is terribly powerful. Because I do hope to see signs of new economic recovery, we do hope to be in a position to make those types of decisions. But we first need to see some credible signs of global economic resurgence and we all know we have some difficult waters ahead of us.

Second on aluminum, I think you point out now without a bit of irony that two smelters which have had transformer and rectifier problems have been Australia's inter-smelters and I think it's to say that for many years we had constrained sustaining capital which probably has caught up with us. We do need to recognize that, in Anglesea in particular which we knew had a fairly short shelf life as a consequence of the uncertainty around local nuclear capacity and local power contracts that by the nature would have been good for our business to not necessarily keep those transformers ready to run for the next 15 years, because we know we didn't have 15 years of power contracts and that was treated accordingly. In both the case of the Anglesea and the Anzus power failures, we have taken those lessons learned and apply them through the rest of the Group. And this would be an area I think where the superior technical position and the leading technical position that we -- that came into the Group through the Alcan transaction is probably helping the total global set of smelters.
And a question here. So we take probably one more question, then we are going to wrap up actually.
Okay, thanks Nigel.
Back there . Pick up the mic please?

It's Paul Mitchell from Credit Suisse. Happy to be lucky last. Hopefully it's an easy question. Just looking at the regional pricing allocations you may draw in the Alcan acquisition, I note in I think its page 33 of your release that in fact goodwill is written off from 14.5 billion to what was allocated from 14.5 to 20.1 billion. So my question was the subsequent impairment charge that we saw through for goodwill to that 6.6 billion. Is that after that impact, so we actually kind of increased it 5.5 and then wrote it back for 6.5? Am I reading that correctly?

Perhaps I better take that one. Paul , in a way you are right, I mean we -- as a result of the Dodge Phelps activity that took place over the year following acquisition we were able to examine in depth what the value of each asset was and that causes to reallocate as you can see, mainly in the area of tangible assets, but also intangible assets, the fair value of Alcan. The difference was predominantly into goodwill. And then you can see that number rose up to $20 billion. And with the impairment it will obviously reduce again down to a bit less than 14. And the cause is of the goodwill adjustment, though where the ones I explained namely; recognition of different economic circumstances, higher input costs, and the removal from our assessment of value of those projects which we had deferred or chosen to differ. So I think that nevertheless your observation as a quite a lot of merit to it. It is kind of backward than forward or forward than backward.

No, I think probably we have to draw the line there unfortunately to keep on the schedule which is rather tight. But just to say thank you all again for being here, and sitting through all this time of being rather extended presentations, but I hope the content was helpful to you. Thank you for coming.
